subtitle: Thinking Allowed
Conversations on the leading edge of knowledge and discovery with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove
Hello. I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. Today I’d like to talk about one of my heroes, William James, and an
interesting episode that occurred in my life.
You see, William James is one of the great thinkers in American history. He’s considered the founder of
American
psychology, and the founder of American
religious studies. And a great philosopher, too, one of the founders of the American
Pragmatic School of Philosophy. In fact, I believe, one study recently
listed him as among the hundred most influential
Americans of all time.
I admired William James
particularly because he was actively engaged in psychical research. He
was deeply concerned about the question of life after death.
He became, in fact, at one time, a president of the Society for Psychical Research in England, and
one of the founders, as I recall, of the American Society for Psychical Research.
Now, I
liked
William James and found so much inspiration in his life that I actually have the URL of WilliamJames.com.
If you click on it, it will
forward you to the New Thinking Allowed video channel on YouTube.
Many years ago - about 20 years ago - I was interviewing
medical doctor Walter Semkiw, who had written a book on astrology. I was interviewing him, and he
said to me,
he noted that I had the WilliamJames.com
website, and he said, “Could you have been William James in a past lifetime?” I mean, there’s some
reason for him to have thought so, I suppose, because of my fascination with William James, of the fact that I
acquired that URL WilliamJames.com, and
the fact that
William James was an important pioneer in the field of psychical research, the study of
unusual mental abilities and particularly survival after death, and here am I,
the only
the only person ever to have received a doctoral diploma that says
Parapsychology anywhere in the world.
So one might think there was a linkage, but I told Walter, “Of course not. I
wasn’t William James in a past life. He is one of my heroes, how could I have been him?”
And Semkiw said to me,
“Well, the way he sees it, people
incarnate together in soul groups."
He had,
at that time, not published his book Return of the Revolutionaries, but he was working on it and he told me he
believed he could identify many people alive today who were
members of the Founding Father group of the United States. The Founding Fathers of this country were
reincarnating today.
He had a method that he used. He worked with a trance channel to confirm his
thinking in this area. Then the trance channel was my good friend Kevin Ryerson, so Walter said
to me, “Here’s what you could do. See about people who are close to you, members that you might call ‘of your
own’ soul group, and see if they match up in some ways in terms of personality,
interests,
talents and
facial features,
with people
who were known to have been close to William James.” And so I did that, and to my surprise, i found
yes, quite a number of people who were important in my life
also seemed to bear a resemblance to people
who were important in the life of William James. And I allowed Walter to publish a section
about that in his book, Return of the
Revolutionaries, but I have to say I wasn’t fully convinced, especially because I had no
memories of having been William James.
So, I actually
participated in a series of
hypnotic regressions to see if I could come up with memories of William James, and those
regressions were
performed by my friend, a medical doctor, Charles Tramont,
who later wrote about them in a book he wrote about past lives.
But
honestly, nothing
came up
by way of memories. The most that I could say is that during the hypnotic
sessions, I would often come out of it with a feeling in my stomach, a painful feeling. And the truth is, William James,
for all of his greatness, was a sickly man, and
he suffered from depression, he suffered from a variety of bodily
ailments. And
under hypnosis I seemed to experience some of those. But,
I don’t count that as being
evidential, because I knew about all that to begin with. You know, the power of suggestion is quite strong.
But there were these - I guess you’d have to say
‘coincidences’, probably not synchronicities in the Jungian sense, but coincidences - that many people in my life,
including myself, seemed to match up with people
in the life of William James. And I think I even do bear some physical resemblance
to him. But what I want to talk about is
the fact that
William James
overcame his depression, overcame his illnesses. Back in the
19th century - he lived, died in 1910, as I recall, or 1909 - he
became acquainted with the American Transcendentalist movement. His father was a close friend of people like
Emerson and Thoreau and Chandler and the other leaders of
that movement, American Transcendentalism, a very important literary and philosophical
movement centered in Boston, where he lived.
He became acquainted with the work of Émile Coué - a French
pedagogue, I
believe - who used to have people repeat the positive affirmation: “In every day, in every way, I am getting better
and better.” And James discovered that by using mental
suggestion he could overcome his own depression.
In fact, he wrote that the greatest discovery of his generation is that we can
change our life by changing our thoughts. As
a result of that he achieved a life of
Greatness. Now let me come back
again to the question of reincarnation, because it’s worth mentioning that
what I did do as a result of this and other potential past life
identifications that
seemed to me to be almost
real but not quite. I developed a theory of my own, in conjunction with a
psychologist from the East Coast, Brendan Engen, we call it “archetypal
synchronistic resonance.” It’s where you have a
resonance with, in our case in particular,
heroic figures from the past where there seemed to be many coincidences and many -
well, I guess resonances is the best word. We seem to be on the same wavelength, and
many
synchronicities and various kinds of paranormal events
seem to occur when this happens at an archetypal level. Now, archetype is an
unusual word. It’s developed by the
psychologist, the great Swiss psychiatrist, Carl Jung.
Often, I’ve asked my students to define - what is an archetype? - and they all have good answers, I can
tell you that, but the answers tend to be a little different. Archetype is a very elusive term, one could call it a
constellation,
a whirlwind almost, of energy and ideas, that exists in the psyche itself. And an archetype can
take on a life of its
own, like a deity, like a conscious being that exists only in the
psychic or mental or spiritual world.
These archetypes may be
responsible for coincidences that occur in our lives, and much more than that in fact. Archetypes can
affect the whole course of our destiny.
Two wonderful books
were written about archetypes by the
psychiatrist Jean Shinoda Bolen, Gods in Everyman
and Goddesses in Everywoman.
This can be positive or negative, because, sometimes when your life
is driven by an archetype, it has a dark side, and if you’re not conscious of it the dark side can take
control. So it’s better to be conscious of the
dominant archetypes in your life. I think it’s fair to say that William James
functions as an archetype in my life, in the sense of being, I’d like to think, a guiding spirit.
And so,
I want to leave you with the thought, as
voiced by William James, that you can change your life by changing the way you think.
And you can change the way you think through self-suggestion, or sometimes people use the term
affirmations. The things that you say to yourself, the way you talk to yourself,
can be so crucial and you can learn to stop talking to yourself in negative
ways, if that’s what you’re doing, and to
reinforce the positive things in your life, as William James did dramatically, by
holding thoughts in your mind that are positive. You know, I mentioned in an earlier
edition of
“In Presence”, that another great inspiration for me has been Rudolf Steiner, a
philosopher and a mystic, who said that, “our thoughts, our very thoughts, are
spiritual entities, they are alive, and we can learn to work with our thoughts in powerful ways.” I
think about that a lot and I’d like you to give it some thought yourself. How can you
change your life by changing your thoughts?
I’ll leave you with that question to ponder.
Thank you for being with me.
you
